bestBHT.bht: The rejection and crucifixion of Jesus by the Jewish rulers was intensified by their knowledge that He was the Messiah, as foretold by Caiaphas. The parable of the vineyard owner's son draws upon the history of Joseph's rejection by his brothers, a deep typology of Jesus' own rejection and exaltation. Their plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance reflects the deceitful desires of the depraved heart. It is a futile attempt to maintain their own authority by defying God.

Henry Alford: The latent consciousness that Jesus was the Messiah, expressed in the prophecy of Caiaphas, added no doubt to the guilt of the Jewish rulers in rejecting and crucifying Him."

The very words of Gen. xxxvii. 20, where Joseph’s brethren express a similar resolution: and no doubt used by the Lord in reference to that history, so deeply typical of His rejection and exaltation."
As far as this, the parable is History: from this point, Prophecy.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This is the heir—Sublime expression this of the great truth, that God's inheritance was destined for, and in due time is to come into the possession of, His own Son in our nature.
Come, let us kill him, and let us seize on his inheritance—that so, from mere servants, we may become lords.
This is the deep aim of the depraved heart; this is emphatically 'the root of all evil.'
Philip Schaff: ‘Heir’ in virtue of His human nature, Hebrews 1:1-2.
An expression of folly (in addition to the wicked resolve), as though the death of the heir would permit them to hold the possession, while the householder lived.
In the attempt to maintain their own authority, which He had challenged, by putting Him to death, they foolishly defied God.
Archibald T. Robertson: Take his inheritance (σχωμεν την κληρονομιαν αυτου). Ingressive aorist active subjunctive (hortatory, volitive) of εχω. Let us get his inheritance.
John Gill: When they saw Jesus of Nazareth, they knew by various circumstances, by all the characters of the Messiah meeting in him, and by his miracles, that he must be the same.

He is heir of all that his Father has, as he is his natural, essential, and only begotten Son; and as mediator, he is heir of all things, natural, spiritual, and eternal, for the use and benefit of his church and people.

Concluding, that could they be rid of him, their nation would be in peace, their temple would stand, and temple worship and service continue, and they remain in their office and authority undisturbed; the contrary of which they feared, should he be suffered to live; though what they feared from his life, befell them upon, and in consequence of his death, quite beyond all their counsels and expectations.

bhtAttempts.bht: The rejection and crucifixion of Jesus by the Jewish rulers was intensified by their knowledge that He was the Messiah, as foretold by Caiaphas. The parable of the vineyard owner's son draws upon the history of Joseph's rejection by his brothers, a deep typology of Jesus' own rejection and exaltation. Their plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance reflects the deceitful desires of the depraved heart. It is a futile attempt to maintain their own authority by defying God.

The rejection and crucifixion of Jesus by the Jewish rulers was intensified by their knowledge that He was the Messiah, as foretold by Caiaphas. The parable of the vineyard owner's son draws upon the history of Joseph's rejection as a powerful symbol of Jesus' own rejection and ultimate exaltation. Their plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance reveals the deceitful desires of the depraved heart. It is a futile attempt to maintain their own authority by defying God's plan.

The guilt of the Jewish rulers in rejecting and crucifying Jesus was heightened by their awareness that He was the prophesied Messiah. The parable of the vineyard owner's son alludes to the history of Joseph's rejection and points to Jesus' own rejection and exaltation. The plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance exposes the corrupt desires of the heart, driven by the misguided hope of retaining authority. However, this futile act only defies God's plan and leads to their ultimate downfall.

The rejection and crucifixion of Jesus by the Jewish rulers was intensified by their knowledge that He was the Messiah, as foretold by Caiaphas. The parable of the vineyard owner's son draws upon the history of Joseph's rejection by his brothers, a deep typology of Jesus' own rejection and exaltation. Their plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance reflects the deceitful desires of the depraved heart. It is a futile attempt to maintain their own authority by defying God.

The rejection and crucifixion of Jesus by the Jewish rulers was intensified by their knowledge of His Messiahship, as foreseen by Caiaphas. The parable of the vineyard owner's son draws from Joseph's story as a poignant allegory for Jesus' own rejection and subsequent exaltation. The plot to kill the heir and seize his inheritance reveals the corrupt motives of the wicked heart, driven by the misguided quest for power. In their defiance of God's plan, they unknowingly seal their own downfall.
